summary:
This is an introductory Kotlin course.
- The course will be most beneficial for beginner-level Kotlin learners.
- The course covers core Kotlin features.
- It contains hands-on examples of Kotlin code implementation and exercises to practice new skills.
- The course is based on the author's personal experience in Kotlin development.
title: Introduction to Coding

task_list.name: hello-world
task_list.description_text:
Hello World

This is an introductory course to the Kotlin Programming Language, made by Laslo Hauschild. It is meant for absolute beginners.

Kotlin uses the Java Virtual Machine to run its code. That means, everything that works with Java works with Kotlin. Kotlin is the better Java. In 2016, Google announced to replace Java with Kotlin as the preferred language for Android App Development. And its usage go much further.

Your very first program will do the following: Output Hello World in the console. Use the hints below as instructions. 


    fun main {
      //Your code goes here.
    }
Use println("Your text here") to output something to the console.
Use the Check-Button below to check your answer

task_list.name: introduction
task_list.description_text:
Math with Kotlin

Disclaimer: This lesson is meant to be taught by an experienced programmer.

Computers are great in two things: Math and storing data.
Today, we are going to cover the math part.
This is very important to become a good programmer. It would be optimal if you had someone teaching you this instead of learing it yourself.

Start off by trying to put some basic addition, e.g. "1 + 2" into a print statement. It is explained in the first hint again. Don't forget to put Quotation Marks.

Use println("Your text here") to output something to the console.
Open this after you tried

As you may have noticed, it didn't do any math. That's because a print statement with quotation marks takes the input as a String, which is the word for Text in programming.

Please go on with the next lesson.

task_list.name: math
task_list.description_text:
Math with Kotlin

Try the same thing again, but this time without the quotation marks. It should act like a calculator. So, lets go over some operations.

Try to do simple addition. How does it work?

Use + to do addition.

Try to do the same with subtraction.

Use - to do subtraction.

Try out multiplication. If you can't figure out what symbol is used, feel free to use the hint.

Use * to do multiplication.

Division? Pay attention if it rounds, and if yes up or down? What happens if you replace something like 3 / 2 by 3.0 / 2.0

Use / to do division. Kotlin has two major types of numbers. These are Integer and Double.. An Integer can represent every whole number, while a Double also supports decimal places. When doing an Integer Division, Kotlin will always round down.

Does Kotlin follow BEDMAS? Does it support ( or ) ? Try it out!

Kotlin follows the BEDMAS rules. That also means you can use ( and ).

task_list.name: comparison
task_list.description_text:
Compare numbers to each other.

Often, we need to compare numbers. In Kotlin, we use these operators for it:

< corresponds to is smaller than. Examples: 3 < 2 is false. 5 < 16 is true. 7 < 7 is false.

> corresponds to is bigger than. Examples: 3 > 2 is true. 5 > 16 is false. 7 > 7 is false.

== corresponds to is equal Examples: 3 == 2 is false. 5 == 16 is false. 7 == 7 is true.

<= corresponds to is smaller or equal to. Examples: 3 <= 2 is false. 5 <= 16 is true. 7 <= 7 is true.

>= corresponds to is bigger or equal to. Examples: 3 >= 2 is true. 5 >= 16 is false. 7 >= 7 is true.

Take the time and try to put some of these statements into a print statement.

task_list.name: Declare Variables
task_list.description_text:
Variables

Disclaimer: This lesson should be taught by an experienced programmer.

The second thing that computers are incredibly good in, is storing data. I am going to show you the most convenient way in Kotlin.

Before we store data, we have to understand data types. You already know a few:

  • String [Text]
  • Integer, called Int [Whole numbers]
  • Double [Numbers with decimal places]

Before you reveal the hints, try to guess how it could work, if you have an idea. That way, you learn more efficient.

Write a program that begins with a variable with the value "Hello World". Try the following things in the code:

  • Print the variable.
  • Change the value in it and print it.
  • Try to change it to a number and print it.
  • Create a new variable with a number in it and do math with it. Use print statements for that.
  • Save the output of a calculation in a variable and print it later.
  • Compare variables instead of numbers, the same way. Also compare a variable to a number.
How you store data:
var [name of variable] = [some data]
Example:
var data = "Hello World!"
You can access the data like that:
var data = "Hello World"
print(data)
You can also specify the type of data to be stored:
var data: String = "Hello World!"
If you want to change the value, simply reassign the variable:
data = "Something else"
That will delete the previous value in the variable, and put a new value into it.
There may be some cases where you want a variable to be unchangeable. It also helps to understand the code, so try to use this feature as often as possible.
val moreData = "This is unmodifiable, because it starts with the keyword val"

task_list.name: If-Statement
task_list.description_text:
IF-Statement

We are going to take a look at if-statements. They job is very important. You can add optional code, depending on what the situation is. 


    if (something) {
         //Do stuff
    }

The something is replaced with a boolean. It is a data type that has exactly two states: true or false.

You already know some of these booleans. They occur when comparing two numbers to each other. So, an example of a program with an if-statement could be this: 


    val number = 3
    if (number < 6) {
         print("The number is smaller than six!")
    }
